questions.text: The patient's blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Four different sphygmomanometers measure his BP, each with 3 readings. Match the sphygmomanometers with their respective accuracy and precision parameters. Sphygmomanometer readings Accuracy and Precision parameters 1. 120/80, 120/80, 120/80 a. Precise but inaccurate 2. 140/96, 108/62, 96/82 b. Imprecise but accurate 3. 140/96, 140/96, 140/96 c. Precise and accurate 4. 122/82, 120/80, 118/78 d. Imprecise and inaccurate
questions.explanation:
Accurate & precise

Not accurate & precise

Accurate & not precise

Not accurate & not precise

Every line hits the central point exactly at the gold standard value.

The same finding is seen, but far from the true value; it is inaccurate.

It is accurate as the result is closer to the true value in the first circle; it is not precise.

It is not precise or accurate.

questions.text: All comprise inherent properties of a screening test except?

A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain and the doctor suspects myocardial infraction thus orders a blood test to evaluate for a specific cardiac marker for the same which has a sensitivity of 95% and a specificity of 90%. In the general population, the prevalence of acute myocardial infarction is 2%, while in patients presenting to the emergency department with chest pain, the prevalence increases to 30%. Based on this scenario, which of the following statements is true concerning the test?

options.label: A
options.text: Positive predictive value remains constant when prevalence <25%

options.label: B
options.text: Negative predictive value increases as prevalence increases

options.label: C
options.text: Positive predictive value is directly proportional to the prevalence

options.label: D
options.text: Negative predictive value remains constant when prevalence >75%

questions.correct_answer: C. Positive predictive value is directly proportional to the prevalence

questions.text: Among the population of 5 million people in a city, 1 in every 200 undergoes sudden cardiac arrest each year. A new government formed recently wanted to know the total number of sudden cardiac arrests in this population during the last 5 years. What will be the estimate per million population?
questions.explanation: Prevalence = Incidence x Duration

questions.text: In a population of 1000 people who are at high risk of contracting syphilis, 650 were confirmed to be positive by serological studies. A new test that acts by detecting a new biomarker "X" has been introduced and 600 were found to be positive among serology-positive patients. 120 out of the remaining 350 people were also found to be having “X”. What is the positive predictive value of this new test?
questions.explanation:
Serology positive

Serology negative

"X" positive

600

(a-true positive)

120

(b-false positive)

"X" negative

50

(c-false negative)

230

(d-true negative)

questions.text: A new imaging test has been introduced to diagnose breast cancer in a sample of 1500 people. Among those 600 people who have biopsy-confirmed breast carcinoma, 480 were found to be positive. 60 were also found positive among the remaining 900 biopsy-negative people. What is the sensitivity and specificity of this new test, respectively?
questions.explanation:
Biopsy positive

Biopsy negative

BRight positive

480

(a- true positive)

60

(b- false positive)

BRight negative

120

(c- false negative)

840

(d- true negative)

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding Cronbach's alpha?

options.label: A
options.text: Cronbach's alpha is a measure of internal consistency reliability.

options.label: B
options.text: It ranges from 0 to 1, with higher values indicating greater reliability.

options.label: C
options.text: Cronbach's alpha can be used to assess the validity of a measurement instrument.

options.label: D
options.text: Cronbach's alpha assumes that all items in the scale measure the same underlying construct.

questions.correct_answer: C. Cronbach's alpha can be used to assess the validity of a measurement instrument.

questions.text: Sensitivity/(1-specificity) is the formula to find which among the following?
questions.explanation:
Positive likelihood ratio

Negative likelihood ratio
  • It represents how much more likely a positive test result is in individuals with the disease than those without it.
  • LR+ > 1 indicates a positive test result is more likely in those with the disease.
  • Higher LR+ values (>10) indicate strong evidence of disease.
  • Indicates how much less likely a negative test result is in individuals with the disease compared to those without the disease.
  • LR- < 1 indicates a negative test result is less likely in those with the disease.
  • Lower LR- values (<0.1) suggest strong evidence for excluding the disease.

questions.text: What purpose is Kaplan-Meier analysis used primarily for?

options.label: A
options.text: Assessing the impact of economic factors on survival rates.

options.label: B
options.text: Estimating the probability of survival over time.

options.label: C
options.text: Analysing the correlation between lifestyle choices and health outcomes.

options.label: D
options.text: Predicting future trends in population demographics.

questions.correct_answer: B. Estimating the probability of survival over time.

questions.text: Given below are a few statements regarding the receiver operating curve. Which among the following is a false statement?

options.label: A
options.text: The best investigation is the one whose curve is most upward and left

options.label: B
options.text: The test with the minimum surface area under the cure is the most effective

options.label: C
options.text: Can be used for comparing two or more diagnostic tests

options.label: D
options.text: Can be used for deciding optimal cut-off points

questions.correct_answer: B. The test with the minimum surface area under the cure is the most effective

questions.text: Below is a graph showing the results of a screening test. If the cut-off point is reduced from point B to A, what will be its effect on this screening test?
Screening of syphilis RPR test is done first. All those positive on RPR are submitted to FTA-ABS. Multiple tests were done in parallel. What will be seen ?
questions.explanation:
Tests done in series

Tests done in parallel
  • A population is subjected to one screening test followed by a second one.
  • The second test is done only if the first test is positive.
  • Multiple tests are done concurrently.
  • A person is considered positive for disease if any tests give a positive result.

 

Tests in series

Tests in parallel

Sensitivity

Decreases

Increases

Specificity

Increases

Decreases

PPV

Increases

Decreases

NPV

Decreases

Increases

PPV: Positive predictive value, NPV: Negative predictive value.

questions.text: A 40-year-old healthy man visits his family physician for a routine check-up. His physician recommends a series of tests to identify potential diseases that might be present without causing symptoms. This proactive approach is an example of which of the following?
The diagnostic power of a test to correctly exclude the disease is reflected by?
Specificity is a property of a screening test .Specificity of a test means all except?

options.label: A
options.text: Refers to the ability of a test to identify those without a condition as negative.

options.label: B
options.text: It is calculated as the ratio of true negatives to the sum of true negatives and false positives.

options.label: C
options.text: A highly specific test will rarely produce false positives.

options.label: D
options.text: It is related to the condition's prevalence in the population being tested.

questions.correct_answer: D. It is related to the condition's prevalence in the population being tested.

questions.text: Sensitivity is the ability of a test to detect?

options.label: A
options.text: Individuals who do not have the disease

options.label: C
options.text: Individuals who have the disease but test negative

options.label: D
options.text: Individuals who do not have the disease but test positive

questions.correct_answer: B. Individuals who have the disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not a test used for assessing accuracy?

A 45-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with chest pain. An ECG is performed. Doctor 1 reviews the ECG and reports it as normal. However, Doctor 2 reviewed the same ECG and reported that it was abnormal. What is the most likely explanation for the differing interpretations of the patient's ECG by Doctor 1 and Doctor 2?
questions.explanation:
Observer Variability

Biological Variation

Errors Related to Technology

Interobserver Variation:

  • Differences between different observers.
  • Example: Two doctors interpret the same ECG differently, which leads to different diagnoses.
  • Natural changes in a patient's physiological parameters over time.
  • For example, blood pressure fluctuates daily, and cholesterol levels vary with diet.
  • Inaccuracies in measurement are due to malfunctioning equipment.
  • For example, a faulty thermometer gives inconsistent temperatures.

Intraobserver Variation:

  • Differences in interpretation by the same observer at different times.
  • Example: The same doctor interprets an ECG differently when reviewed at different times.

questions.text: During the COVID-19 pandemic, airports implemented temperature checks and rapid antigen tests for passengers. This is an example of what type of screening?
questions.explanation:
Prescriptive Screening (Option B)

Prospective Screening (Option A)
  • Done for one's own benefit.
  • Secondary level of prevention.
  • Early diagnosis.
  • Done for other's benefit.
  • The primary level of prevention.
  • Control/ prevention of disease.

E.g.

  • Screening neonates for neonatal hypothyroidism
  • Deafness in children
  • Blood glucose testing for diabetes mellitus and gestational diabetes
  • Mammography for breast cancer
  • Pap smear for cervical cancer
  • Visual acuity for refractive errors.

E.g.

  • Screening of immigrants for diseases like TB and COVID
  • HIV screening for blood donation
  • HIV screening in ANC cases
  • Health checkups for workers in the food industry.

questions.text: A health camp was organized to conduct cervical cancer screening in pregnant females. Which of the following best explains this type of screening test?
questions.explanation:
1. Mass Screening (OPTION C)
  • All individuals screened irrespective of high risk.
  • Least efficient type of screening.

2. High-risk screening/ selective screening/ targeted screening

(OPTION A)
  • Only high-risk individuals are screened.
  • Most efficient form of screening.
  • E.g.:
    • Hypertension screening in the elderly.
    • TB screening in lower socio-economic population.
    • Breast cancer screening with a family history of breast cancer.

3. Multiphasic screening
  • Application of 2 or more screening tests in combination to a large number of people at one time to detect a single disease.
  • E.g., Health camps for cervical cancer: Questionnaire, Pap smear, Visual inspection.

4. Multipurpose screening (OPTION D)
  • Screen the population with more than one test done simultaneously to detect more than one disease
  • Screening blood tests of pregnant females (Hb, RA, HIV, VDRL, HbsAg)

5. Opportunistic screening or Case-finding
  • Screening conducted during routine healthcare visits for other reasons
  • Presumptive identification was not raised at the patient's request
  • E.g., Screen everyone above 30 for hypertension

questions.text: Which of the following statements about diseases suitable for screening is true? The disease should have a significant impact on public health. Early detection and treatment should reduce morbidity. The disease should have a short latent period. A reliable, invasive, and cost-effective screening test should be available. The disease should have a high prevalence in the population.
Which of the following appropriately represents lead time in the given figure
All of the following are features of a screening test except?

options.label: A
options.text: Aimed at early detection of disease in asymptomatic individuals.

options.label: B
options.text: High specificity is more important than high sensitivity.

options.label: C
options.text: Often less accurate and applied to a large population.

options.label: D
options.text: Typically involves simple, cost-effective and non-invasive procedures.

questions.correct_answer: B. High specificity is more important than high sensitivity.
questions.explanation:
Screening test

Diagnostic test

Done on apparently healthy people (Statement A)

Done on those who are sick

Applied to groups/ large populations (Statement C)

Applied on individuals

Test results are arbitrary and final.

Diagnosis is not final but modified in the light of new evidence/ sum of evidence.

Based on one criterion or cut-off value and lab findings.

Based on the evaluation of signs and symptoms.

Less accurate

More accurate

Tests are simple, non-invasive and cost-effective (Statement D).

Tests are complex, invasive, or costly procedures.

It cannot be used as a basis for treatment.

It can be used as a basis for treatment.

The initiative comes from govt organizations/NGOs.

The initiative comes from the patient.

High sensitivity is prioritized to avoid false negatives.

High specificity is prioritized to avoid false positives.(Statement B)
